May 22, 2024

Release highlights

custom metric function decorator

we’ve introduced a new metric decorator designed to turn any function into a ValidMind Metric. Custom metrics offer added flexibility by allowing you to extend the library of default metrics provided by ValidMind. This enables you to document any type of model or use case.

The new decorator simplifies the process of creating and using custom metrics by almost completely eliminating the boilerplate code required to define and register a custom metric.

check out the new notebook to see how you can start using custom metrics in your documentation

support for external models

you can now run documentation tests without passing a Python-native model object. This enables documenting:

models developed in non-python environments

non-standard model interfaces:

  • models deployed as APIs, e.g., SageMaker model endpoints
  • tools such as Spark where a “model” is not a typical object that exposes a predict() interface

run tests for these models

To run tests for these models, you typically need to load model predictions from a file, dataset, etc. The new init_model interface does not enforce a Python model object anymore. You only need to pass attributes that describe the model. This is required as a best practice for model documentation.

initializing an external model

Since there is no native Python object to pass to init_model, you need to pass attributes that describe the model:

# Assume you want to load predictions for a PySpark ML model
model_attributes = {
    "architecture": "Spark",
    "language": "PySpark",
}

# Or maybe you're loading predictions for a SageMaker endpoint (model API)
model_attributes = {
    "architecture": "SageMaker Model",
    "language": "Python",
}

Call init_model without passing a model

Pass attributes instead:

vm_model = vm.init_model(
    attributes=model_attributes,
    input_id="model"
)

assigning predictions

Since there’s no model object available, the developer framework won’t be able to call model.predict() and model.predict_proba(). You will need to load predictions and probabilities manually:

vm_train_ds.assign_predictions(
    model=vm_model,
    prediction_values=prediction_values,
    prediction_probabilities=prediction_probabilities,
)

run tests as usual

You can run tests as usual. No other changes are needed.

new introductory notebook for model developers

new introductory notebook for model developers

This notebook gives you a full introduction to the developer framework and teaches you how to document a model end-to-end.

high level sections:

1. initialize the ValidMind developer framework

The ValidMind Developer Framework provides a rich collection of documentation tools and test suites. These range from documenting descriptions of datasets to validating and testing models using various open-source testing frameworks.

2. start the model development process with raw data, run out-of-the-box tests and add evidence to model documentation

At this stage, the notebook provides details on how to access ValidMind’s test repository of individual tests. You will use these as building blocks to ensure a model is being built appropriately. The goal is to show how to run tests, investigate results, and add test results/evidence to the documentation.

For a full list of out-of-box tests, please refer to: https://docs.validmind.com/guide/test-descriptions.html

3. learn how to implement custom tests

Usually, you have many custom tests that are important to include in the model documentation. This section shows how to include custom tests and then how they can be added as additional evidence in the documentation.

4. ensure completion of documentation

In this stage, the notebook demonstrates how to ensure that model documentation includes custom tests. You will also learn how to make test configuration changes applicable to all tests in the model documentation template. By the end of this section, you should have a fully documented model ready for review.

documentation outline page (unresolved conversations)

created a new documentation outline page

This page shows a section-by-section outline of your project’s documentation as well as a count of every unresolved conversation within each section.

You may hover over the Chat icon to see a preview of all unresolved conversations. Click them to jump to the specific conversation.

You may also choose to resolve conversations directly from the popup.

add business unit and risk area at organization setting

features

new features in organization page:

  • add business unit
  • add risk area
  • remove business unit
  • remove risk area

new documentation overview page

with this new update

documentation overview page

The documentation overview page is now more distinct from the model detail page. This change provides an easier way for you to navigate into sections. Enhanced data visualization helps you better understand the progress of the documentation stage.

documentation outline page (unresolved conversations)

  • created a new documentation outline page, which replaces the existing project overview page.

  • this page shows a section-by-section outline of your project’s documentation as well as a count of every unresolved conversation within each section.

  • you may hover over the Chat icon to see a preview of all unresolved conversations and click them to jump to them.

  • you may also choose to resolve conversations directly from the popup

add business unit and risk area at organization setting

features

new features in organization page:

  • add business unit
  • add risk area
  • remove business unit
  • remove risk area

new documentation overview page

with this new update, the documentation overview page is more distinct from the model detail page. You now have an easier way to navigate into the sections with enhanced data visualization. This helps you better understand the progress of the documentation stage.

added generate_with_ai button to the CKEditor

  • added a Generate with AI button to the text editor

The Generate with AI button appears within the text blocks in Model Documentation and Model Validation. This new button replaces the old one that was used to AI-generate content.

  • clicking on Generate with AI

Clicking on the Generate with AI button pops up a modal showing the AI content generation. Here, you can choose to Accept or Try Again.

workflows 2

revamped workflows feature

The new Workflows UI includes the following features:

  • ability to require a user action (approve, reject, request changes, etc.) before updating the status of a resource. The user action appears to relevant users as an action button.
  • ability to define the conditions that need to be met before allowing state transitions on a workflow. These conditions can be evaluated from attribute values of the inventory model.
  • support for approval steps. Approval steps allow you to define the model attribute where a list of approver users needs to be retrieved and the percentage of approvals required for successful approval.
  • approval steps allow defining approved and rejected outcomes.

For more details, please visit our documentation.

add, remove, and rename sections with the new template editing experience

this update allows users to edit templates visually, eliminating the need to manually edit YAML files.

key features:

  • enhanced template setting page:
    • the edit button next to the version dropdown is now hidden.
    • a new edit button is displayed above the accordions. Clicking this button activates edit mode for the accordion.
  • edit mode functionality:
    • in edit mode, you can see a cancel button to exit edit mode and a button to publish a new version of the template with current changes.
    • you can edit section titles when the accordion is in edit mode.
    • you can insert new sections before or after an existing section, or insert a sub-section.
    • you can remove sections with a confirmational alert to ensure the action.

this new visual editing interface streamlines the template editing process, making it more intuitive and user-friendly.

https://github.com/validmind/frontend/assets/3985459/a8d38a22-d3e5-4d96-8299-f1f19fc64366 https://github.com/validmind/frontend/assets/3985459/14b8d89d-4438-45b0-a050-60c1e23dc53e

Enhancements

ability to compose a metric by combining

validmind now supports the ability to compose multiple unit metrics into complex outputs.

You can log these composite metrics as a single result. This result can be used as a content block in your documentation. The result updates automatically when you re-run the documentation test suite.

support adding new extra columns on the fly

added support for two new VM dataset methods: add_extra_column() and get_extra_column()

add_extra_column()

You can now register arbitrary extra columns in a dataset when a test needs to compute metrics outside of the existing (features, targets, predictions) sets of columns.

An example is when credit risk-related metrics require access to a list of scores computed from predictions. In this case, there needs to be an extra column called scores that you use for computing the metrics.

Example usage:

python

# Init your dataset as usual
vm_train_ds = vm.init_dataset(
    dataset=train_df,
    input_id="train_dataset",
    target_column=customer_churn.target_column,
)

# Generate scores using a user-defined function:
scores = compute_my_scores(x_train)

# Assign a new "scores" column to vm_train_ds:
vm_train_ds.add_extra_column("scores", scores)

This function throws an error if no column values are passed:

python

vm_train_ds.add_extra_column("scores")

ValueError: Column values must be provided when the column doesn't exist in the dataset

You can also use init_dataset with a dataset that has precomputed scores, like this:

>
train_df.columns
Index(['CreditScore', 'Gender', 'Age', 'Tenure', 'Balance', 'NumOfProducts',
      'HasCrCard', 'IsActiveMember', 'EstimatedSalary', 'Exited',
      'Geography_France', 'Geography_Germany', 'Geography_Spain'], dtype='object')

> train_df["my_scores"] = scores
> train_df.columns
Index(['CreditScore', 'Gender', 'Age', 'Tenure', 'Balance', 'NumOfProducts',
      'HasCrCard', 'IsActiveMember','EstimatedSalary','Exited','Geography_France',
      'Geography_Germany','Geography_Spain','my_scores'],dtype='object')

Make sure you set the feature_columns properly:

python

vm_train_ds = vm.init_dataset(
    dataset=train_df,
    input_id="another_ds",
    feature_columns=[
        "CreditScore", "Gender", "Age", "Tenure","Balance","NumOfProducts",
        "HasCrCard", "IsActiveMember", "EstimatedSalary", 
        "Exited","Geography_France","Geography_Germany","Geography_Spain"
    ],
    target_column=customer_churn.target_column,
)

Then, call `add_extra_column()` to register the extra column:

another_ds.add_extra_column(column_name=“my_scores”)

Column my_scores exists in the dataset, registering as an extra column



### get_extra_column()

You can use this inside a test to retrieve the extra column values. Example:

python

scores = self.inputs.dataset.get_extra_column(“scores”)

### support for metadata in new metric decorator

adding new decorators to support task type and tag metadata in functional metrics

here is an example:

python

copyright © 2023-2024 ValidMind Inc. All rights reserved.

see the LICENSE file in the root of this repository for details.

SPDX-License-Identifier: AGPL-3.0 AND ValidMind Commercial

from sklearn.metrics import accuracy_score

from validmind import tags, tasks

@tasks(“classification”) @tags(“classification”, “sklearn”, “accuracy”) def Accuracy(dataset, model): ““” calculates the accuracy of a model ““” return accuracy_score(dataset.y, dataset.y_pred(model))

the above decorator is syntactic sugar for the following:

Accuracy.__tags__ = [“classification”] Accuracy.__tasks__ = [“classification”, “sklearn”, “accuracy”] ```

metric decorators should work with test providers

adding support for functional metrics for internal tests and test providers

Continuing our efforts to simplify the process for getting your custom code working in ValidMind, we now support functional_metrics, i.e., tests that can be defined as pure functions without any boilerplate.

See how this works and more in our updated tutorial on custom test providers.

review credit scorecard notebook

this PR adds support for assigning prediction_probabilities to assign_predictions.

this allows:

  • assign prediction values and probabilities that have been computed outside ValidMind (VM).
  • incorporate prediction values and probabilities from datasets that already have prediction columns.
  • automate the assignment of prediction values and probabilities within VM.

define and implement required text data validation tests

To ensure the integrity of your data, you need to define and implement text data validation tests. Start by identifying the criteria your data must meet. These could include length, format, or specific content requirements.

Once you know what to validate, create tests for each criterion. For example, check if the text meets a minimum or maximum length. Verify that it follows a specific format like an email address or phone number.

Use coding techniques to implement these tests in your system. Functions in languages like Python can help automate the process. Testing regularly ensures your data remains accurate and reliable

the following tests for text data validation have been added:

  • validmind.data_validation.nlp.LanguageDetection
  • validmind.data_validation.nlp.Toxicity
  • validmind.data_validation.nlp.PolarityAndSubjectivity
  • validmind.data_validation.nlp.Sentiment

to test run notebook: rag_langchain_demo.ipynb

ability to associate a finding with a documentation section

model findings association

You can now associate model findings with sections within your model documentation. Doing so allows you to track findings per severity, section-by-section in the documentation overview page.

findings count

You can see the count of the total number of findings at the top of the documentation overview page. The individual counts per section are also displayed there. You may hover over the finding icon in each section and view related findings, then click on one to jump to it.

https://www.loom.com/share/2c3e2ebc3ae94cfeb23b86af2cdf697

added section statuses to model documentation and overview page

added a status picker to each section of the model documentation page. This allows you to set whether the section is In_Progress or Done.

the documentation overview page has a total count of how many sections have been completed, as well as a checkmark indicating that the section is Done.

added feature to specify a template for rich text custom fields

https://app.shortcut.com/validmind/story/4186/documentation-as-a-customer-admin-i-am-able-to-create-a-custom-field-that-supports-rich-text-editor-format-and-i-am-able

display group information for inventory models

admin users can now modify the group the inventory model belongs to

vendor info during inventory model creation and revised inventory model filters

  • added the ability to flag models as Is_Vendor_Model and specify a vendor name.

  • added Vendor_Model as a filtering flag.

  • improved the look and functionality of model inventory filtering.

validation report overview

  • created a new validation report overview page

  • this page shows a section-by-section outline of the model’s validation report. It includes a total compliance summary for all risk areas associated with the model.

  • you may hover over any section in the report outline to view the current compliance status in the document section.

  • the new validation report page also adds an Add_Finding button

updated the about section to break down the articles into new categories

about valid mind

We’ve revamped our documentation for a cleaner, more intuitive experience. The new About section includes:

  • Product overviews and our glossary are now live here under Features.
  • Releases have been moved here as well.
  • Important documents such as our terms are under Fineprint.
contributing

Under this section you’ll find a brand new set of guides on Contributing. Learn how to engage with the Valid Mind community, read about our brand voice and vision, and more.

For more details:

  • The Valid Mind community: You’re part of the Valid Mind community. Come learn and play with us!

  • Valid Mind style guide: Check out the first official version of the Valid Mind style guide.

sandbox instructions

The sandbox is a testing environment that lets you try out features without affecting the live system. Follow these steps to use the sandbox effectively:

set up your account To begin, set up your sandbox account. Visit the registration page and provide the necessary details. Verify your email address through the confirmation link sent to you.

accessing the sandbox environment After setting up your account, log in to access the sandbox. Navigate to Sandbox Environment and enter your credentials.

testing features Use the sandbox to test new features or changes. Make sure that all functionalities work as expected before applying them to the live system. Use sample data where possible.

reporting issues If you encounter any problems while using the sandbox, report them immediately. Contact support through Support Page with detailed information about the issue.

resetting your environment You can reset your sandbox environment at any time if needed. This reverts all changes and restores default settings. Go to “Settings” and select “Reset Environment.”

understanding limitations Keep in mind that some features might not be available in the sandbox. Check for any limitations mentioned on our Documentation Page.

following best practices Always follow best practices while using the sandbox: - Test extensively before making changes live. - Use descriptive names for test cases. - Document any deviations from expected behavior.

end of instructions

we added getting started information for the new valid mind sandbox environment

You use the sandbox to gain hands-on experience and explore what valid mind offers.

The sandbox mimics a production environment. It includes comprehensive resources such as notebooks with sample code you can run, sample models registered in the model inventory, and draft documentation and validation reports.

Most of our model documentation features are available for you to test in the sandbox. These include automated model testing and documentation, preparing model validation reports, and large language model (LLM) support.

These features provide a rich context for testing and evaluation using realistic models and datasets without any risk to your production environment.

Learn more…

we reworked our quickstart experience to shorten the number of clicks it takes to get you started. you can now access the quickstart from the homepage or our docs site and we direct you to the preferred jupyter_hub version right away. [try it…] (https://docs.validmind.ai)
